1→import Link from "next/link"; 2→ 3→/** 4→ * Formats a date into a readable string (e.g., "January 25, 2026"). 5→ */ 6→function formatDate(date: Date | string): string { 7→ const d = typeof date === "string" ? new Date(date) : date; 8→ return d.toLocaleDateString("en-US", { 9→ year: "numeric", 10→ month: "long", 11→ day: "numeric", 12→ }); 13→} 14→ 15→// Sample blog posts data 16→const posts = [ 17→ { 18→ id: 1, 19→ title: "Getting Started with Next.js 18", 20→ excerpt: 21→ "Learn how to build modern web applications with the latest version of Next.js and its powerful new features.", 22→ date: "January 25, 2026", 23→ category: "Tutorial", 24→ readTime: "5 min read", 25→ }, 26→ { 27→ id: 2, 28→ title: "Understanding React Server Components", 29→ excerpt: 30→ "A deep dive into React Server Components and how they change the way we think about building React applications.", 31→ date: "January 20, 2026", 32→ category: "React", 33→ readTime: "8 min read", 34→ }, 35→ { 36→ id: 3, 37→ title: "Tailwind CSS Tips and Tricks", 38→ excerpt: 39→ "Discover advanced techniques and best practices for building beautiful UIs with Tailwind CSS.", 40→ date: "January 15, 2026", 41→ category: "CSS", 42→ readTime: "6 min read", 43→ }, 44→ { 45→ id: 4, 46→ title: "TypeScript Generics Demystified", 47→ excerpt: 48→ "Master TypeScript generics with practical examples. data.prompt: Explore this codebase to understand how blog posts are structured. Find where blog posts are stored, what format they use (markdown, MDX, etc.), and show me an example of an existing blog post file. This appears to be a Next.js project based on the app/page.tsx file.

content.text:
Perfect! Now I have a complete understanding of the blog structure. Let me provide you with a comprehensive report.

## Blog Post Structure Analysis

I've explored your Next.js blog codebase and discovered how blog posts are structured. Here's what I found:

### Blog Post Storage Location
All blog posts are currently stored directly in **/Users/evisdrenova/code/test-entire/app/page.tsx** as TypeScript constants within the component file.

### Format Used
**TypeScript/JavaScript Objects** - The blog posts are stored as plain JavaScript objects in an array, NOT in Markdown or MDX format. This is a simple, in-memory data structure approach.

### Blog Post Data Structure
Each blog post is a JavaScript object with the following properties:

```typescript
{
  id: number,                 // Unique identifier
  title: string,             // Post title
  excerpt: string,           // Short description/preview text
  date: string,              // Publication date (e.g., "January 25, 2026")
  category: string,          // Post category (e.g., "Tutorial", "React", "CSS")
  readTime: string          // Estimated reading time (e.g., "5 min read")
}
```

### Example Blog Post (from current code)
```typescript
{
  id: 1,
  title: "Getting Started with Next.js 18",
  excerpt: "Learn how to build modern web applications with the latest version of Next.js and its powerful new features.",
  date: "January 25, 2026",
  category: "Tutorial",
  readTime: "5 min read",
}
```

### Complete Blog Posts Array
Your project currently has 7 blog posts plus 1 featured post:

1. **"Getting Started with Next.js 18"** - Tutorial (January 25, 2026)
2. **"Understanding React Server Components"** - React (January 20, 2026)
3. **"Tailwind CSS Tips and Tricks"** - CSS (January 15, 2026)
4. **"TypeScript Generics Demystified"** - TypeScript (January 10, 2026)
5. **"Authentication Patterns in Modern Web Apps"** - Security (January 5, 2026)
6. **"New post!"** - Security (January 5, 2026)
7. **"State Management in 2026"** - React (January 2, 2026)

**Featured Post:** "Building a Full-Stack App with Next.js and Postgres" (January 27, 2026)

### Storage Details
- **File Path:** `/Users/evisdrenova/code/test-entire/app/page.tsx`
- **Lines:** 16-80 (posts array), 82-90 (featured post)
- **No file parsing needed** - blog posts are hardcoded as constants

### Current Usage
The blog posts are rendered in the home page component and mapped through using the `.map()` function (line 144). Each post links to `/posts/{post.id}` (line 155), though those individual post pages don't currently exist in the app structure.

### Project Stack
- **Framework:** Next.js 16.1.4
- **Styling:** Tailwind CSS 4
- **Language:** TypeScript
- **React Version:** 19.2.3

This is a simple, static blog implementation. To make it more scalable, you could consider:
- Moving posts to separate Markdown/MDX files in a dedicated `/content/posts` directory
- Using a headless CMS
- Setting up a database
- Creating dynamic post detail pages at `/app/posts/[id]/page.tsx`
